urn:contentItem:5WCJ-3S61-JBHT-D4CJ-00000-00European Markets Close; FTC Investigating Facebook; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks Near Sessions High; U.S. Takes Action on Russia; DOJ and AT&T Face Off; Remington Arms Files for Bankruptcy; Obamacare Premiums to Go Up; NASA Chaplain's Son Inherits Bibles that Went to Moon2018-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:43:39ZLexisNexisEuropean Markets Close; FTC Investigating Facebook; Facebook Under Fire; Stocks Near Sessions High; U.S. Takes Action on Russia; DOJ and AT&T Face Off; Remington Arms Files for Bankruptcy; Obamacare Premiums to Go Up; NASA Chaplain's Son Inherits Bibles that Went to MoonLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I think he has a no choice there.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I think so, too. Yes, they'll send a car right over to take him down there, I think. Neil Cavuto. Thanks, Neil. Appreciate it.

CAVUTO: All right, bud.

WEBSTER: Breaking right now, stocks are soaring after new reports suggest that the White House is quietly negotiating with China as both sides tried to avoid an all-out trade war.

Hello, everybody. I'm Ashley Webster, in today for Trish Regan. And welcome, everyone, to "The Intelligence Report."

Well, investors are encourage by the prospect of the world's two largest economies reaching the deal on trade as stocks bounce back from their worst week in more than two years and optimism apparently spreading beyond Wall Street. Here is Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin speaking to Fox News just yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: I think we're working on a pathway to see if we can reach an agreement as to what fair trade is for them to open up their markets, reduce their tariffs, stop force-technology transfer. These are all the things we want to do. But in a negotiation, you have to be prepared to take action and that's what President Trump is doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: He certainly is. The President displaying his confidence in our economy in a tweet this morning saying, "The economy is looking really good. It has been years that we have seen these kind of numbers. The underlying strength of companies has perhaps never been better." And we'll find out ow those companies are doing, of course, next month with the latest round of earnings.

Joining me now Forbes Media Chairman, the man himself, Steve Forbes. And, Steve, thank you very much for joining us today in the studio.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

WEBSTER: OK. Let's just pick up from what the President said, are you happy with the U.S. economy heading in the right direction. Is it healthy?

FORBES: I think it is healthy. And I think there were news coming out about negotiating with China and these trade disputes is a good thing because one of the things this imposition of tariffs would have done is create uncertainty. Is this thing going to spin out of control?

On the steel side for Japan and China is now been exempted to further negotiations. On the Chinese side, working behind the scenes see what can be done. So I think the markets and investors will be reassured, OK, we can invest. They're not going to let this thing spin out of control.

WEBSTER: Even though, let's be honest, the way its approach is a little chaotic. The Trump administration and it was on this campaign promise list, if you like, so it's not a big surprise but it really did shake the markets. But is this, in your opinion, a classic Donald Trump maneuver? Shoot very high, come out strong, and then bring someone to the table and negotiate perhaps something a little lower?

FORBES: Well, I think, that it would have been better for him and for the economy and investing confidence if they had first, especially with China, negotiated with our European allies, saying we know there are abusers. Our allies know there are abusers. We're going to present the United Front.

Here's what we're going to put on the table. So, you've done that kind of preparation, one, the market wouldn't have freaked out and, two, everyone would have acknowledged, yes, this thing has to be addressed.

WEBSTER: These market actions are remarkable. I was on the 3:00 show last week when we had a 400 point drop and a 700 point drop. Here we go again, the volatility is back. Everything seems now is headline driven. Is that going to be the way for awhile now, do you believe?

FORBES: Well, this is going to depend on what you've referred to early. These earnings are starting to come out next month. But it looks like Corporate America is starting to still turning in good profits.

People say, OK, things are still being done, things are moving ahead. Heck, there was even a story this weekend about "Brexit" in Britain.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FORBES: But for all the hoopla in parliament and the disarray and the ineffective prime minister, things are happening in the economy. It's amazing. Government leaves it alone.

WEBSTER: Despite everything.

FORBES: People do things.

WEBSTER: Well, it's interesting. How much attention does the market or investors pay to what's going on in Washington, because every day there's some headline coming out, whether it's the President's personal lawyer quits or whatever it'd be the story de jure. Does that have an impact on the markets? Are people able to put the noise aside?

FORBES: Most of the noise they put aside, as we've seen with the markets reaction to recently, when concerns about what's going to happen on the trade front came to the forefront. That's when markets thought, my golly, are they going to let this thing spin out of control? Are they going to control it? And so, they respond to that kind of news, not to the latest thing on "60 Minutes" or anything else.

WEBSTER: I know. That's not even news as far I can see it. But anyway, we'll move on.

I have to ask you about Facebook, because in light of the 444 point gain today on Wall Street, it's been striking what we've seen with the selling on Facebook and the hits it continues to take today. We found out the Federal Trade Commission has begun the investigation. Do you have a Facebook page?

FORBES: I do and even own a few shares of Facebook.

WEBSTER: Right. What's your take on all of this?

FORBES: But I think it's a case where management has flubbed the ball. This thing could have been contained from the beginning, be upfront about it. Outline what you're going to do to prevent abuses by users.

Yes, the users violated the contract. But what follow-up did you have? What kind of auditing did you have?

Reassure that you're on top of the things, instead of look like you're floundering, you don't know what to do. You want to go on apology tour. That freaks people out that you're not in charge.

WEBSTER: Is this redeemable at this stage because it's a very good chance to, as Neil Cavuto said, look, he's going to be down in Washington testifying?

FORBES: Yes, and that's like I have an offer you can't refuse kind of invitation.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FORBES: That's going to be critical because that will determine the fate of the stocks in the months ahead, if he goes before the committee and says, here's what happened, here's what we're outlining doing. We think we're on top of this thing, present a role that he is in charge and reassuring and confident, instead of floundering.

WEBSTER: We haven't seen it so far.

FORBES: We haven't seen it, but this is his chance to do it. I hope he is prepping for this thing in a way people say, OK, the government is not going to really move in a big way because if the government moves in, that stock is going to be killed.

WEBSTER: It is. And we're talking about new regulations which could further crimp the business model of Facebook and other social media companies.

FORBES: Yes, and not only Facebook but it means they're going to end up gumming up a lot of other high-tech companies and high-tech start-ups. We don't have the resources to fight this kind thing. So a lot is on his shoulder. I hope the shoulders are broad --

WEBSTER: But don't blow it as they say, Steve.

FORBES: -- well, he brought it on.

WEBSTER: He did, that's very true. Steve, thank you very much. Great stuff as always.

FORBES: Thank you.

WEBSTER: For more on these markets, let's bring in the Stock Swoosh Founder, Melissa Armo, along with Surevest Wealth Management CEO, Rob Luna.

Melissa, let me get to you. What's your take on the markets right now? You need some Pepto-Bismol, don't you? We had a big selloff last week and now here were are up 443 points. Is pretty much this volatility here to stay?

MELISSA ARMO, THE STOCK SWOOSH: Volatility is here to stay. Came in in 2018. I don't think it's going anywhere.

I really didn't look today as a strong day. I know we gapped up a lot this morning. But overall, this is just kind of like a dead-cat bounce, it's something that traders use the terminology.

I really think we might still be lower, because the fact is that overall the market is strong but everything that happens, every headline that comes out, every news thing, the market is reacting very volatile to it, selling off quickly and then bouncing again and selling off quickly.

WEBSTER: Yes.

ARMO: And the range is broadening. We're still strong but the range from the high to where we're at in this base is like wide, it's getting wider and wider and wider.

WEBSTER: Well, it's interesting because, Rob, you say, look, we are trading in a range but to Melissa's point, that range is like the size of the Grand Canyon right now.

ROB LUNA, CEO, SUREVEST WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Well, it's like the size of the Grand Canyon. If you look at the minuscule ranges that we're trading in over the prior 18 to 24 months but I think, you know, in general, there's 11 to 12 percentage point range that we're trading in, you know, quiet honestly, Ashley, is normal. And we got up towards the end at the top of that range, all this headline risk, whether it's tariffs, it's raising interest rates, the market is looking for reason to sell. It got it, now we're back towards the bottom in this range.

And what you're seeing is, as we hit the 200-day moving average support, buyers are starting to come back in this morning. But I look at that last hour, the last hour is going to be very telling to see if we can hold up today.

WEBSTER: Yes. Good luck predicting where it's going go. Let me follow-up with you then, Rob. You say, look, as far as where the economy goes it's all flashing green.

We just spoke with Steve Forbes. He agrees the economy is doing well. We get the earnings next month, assuming they're pretty solid, how important is that for this market?

LUNA: I think it's extremely important, right, because there is a lot of headline risk out there. Right now, investors are definitely nervous. So they need this reassurance from Wall Street, from the companies, from the CEOs out there telling them the things are still good. And I think if that happens, we can head back towards the top of that range, and like we said, that could be eight to 10 percentage-point move. So, if you're an investor you don't necessarily would be on the sidelines and miss out on that.

WEBSTER: That's a good point. Melissa, I spoke with a Money manager this morning who said, look, I'm looking for a sector that has the least downside, the most upside. And I'm thinking, well, yes, we're all doing that, right? He said that sector was energy is being beaten down too much and has a long way to go on the upside. What do you say?

ARMO: I don't agree with that. I like the idea of banks strengths. So right now, the strongest things out there are banks and the tech sector except for Facebook. Take Facebook out of that equation, which is unfortunate.

WEBSTER: Yes.

ARMO: But someone like Amazon, Netflix, Apple, I still like Google still looks good and the banks, J.P. Morgan Chase. I mean, I still think that you buy strong stocks. They're coming in, weak though. Don't buy yet. Wait until they're showing strength for about a week, two weeks.

You want to see consecutive green, green days just like we follow-through and rally today and all next week into the start of April, that will be a good time, come second-quarter earnings season to start getting back into the strong stuff. I don't want to buy stuff that's weak, that's down a lot, that has a huge upside. I want to buy stuff that's proving, that is strong even when the market was falling last week.

WEBSTER: Right. And, Rob, you know, that has been the tech stocks. A lot of money has gone into tech over the last 18 months and beyond. Is that still the leading sector, these big tech companies, or are you seeing money go elsewhere?

LUNA: Yes, you know, I think so, Ashley. You know, really if you were looking at rising interest rates right now, the only way that your portfolio is going to be able to combat that is through growth.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LUNA: And it's very tough to get top-line growth outside of technology right now. The financials could definitely do it but, you know, they're actually been struggling here quite a bit. So, I'm a little bit nervous about what's going on with them.

But the old technology stocks, Amazon, Google, two of our top, you know, largest holdings right now, we're continuing to stick with them. And, I agree, momentum is where you want to be but I don't know that you necessarily wait for them to completely break out. Use this opportunity when they're pulling back technically to enter into positions. And, you know, 10 percent to 15 percent from where they were at before is a pretty attractive entry point in our view.

WEBSTER: Melissa, I want to ask you the same question I asked Steve Forbes. Do you think all the noise is coming out of Washington that at this point investors pay much attention or does it have an impact on the market?

ARMO: Of course, it does have an impact on the market. All you have to do is look last week or even look back the February. It's unfortunate because I think the market is going to shake all of this off.

WEBSTER: Right.

ARMO: But you can't ignore it. We live in 24 hour, seven day week news cycle. Every time you get up, you see this thing, that thing, the other thing. Mr. Forbes is talking about "60 Minutes," I mean even something like that could affected the market this morning.

WEBSTER: That's true.

ARMO: You can't escape it.

WEBSTER: Yes. Rob, what do you tell to your clients? Ignore it, just focus on fundamentals of these companies?

LUNA: Yes, that's exactly it. I mean, when you look at this whole noise about the trade tariffs, we have $375 billion deficit right now. You know, what was on the table is only $60 billion. These are not huge numbers right now.

And let's face it, Trump is not going to get any, you know, style points for finesse here. This is his negotiation style.

WEBSTER: No.

LUNA: He's trying to get China to the table. I think it's a lot of noise right now and investors should just pay attention to the fundamentals.

WEBSTER: Wise words indeed from both of you. Melissa, Rob, thanks you very much for joining us today.

ARMO: Thanks.

LUNA: Thanks, Ashley.

WEBSTER: The Dow up, by the way, 500 points above 24,000. One of those days.

Well, indeed, there may be a rally on Wall Street but shares of Facebook taking another hit after the FTC says it is investigating the company. Can Mark Zuckerberg fix this mess? Our panel discusses it next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Facebook start taking another leg down after the Federal Trade Commission announced it was investigating Facebook's privacy practices. Plus, 37 states attorneys general want to know when Facebook actually knew about that massive data breach. And the Senate Judiciary Committee goes on and on, doesn't it, as invited, I say invited, CEO Mark Zuckerberg and other tech leaders to testify April 10th, an offer they can't refuse as someone put it.

And yes, the headaches keep coming. A new report claims that Facebook logs all your calls and texts, it is. And you probably have no idea that's happening either.

Joining me now to talk about this "Wall Street Journal" Senior Reporter, Shelby Holliday, and our very own, Deirdre Bolton. Thank you both for being here.

Shelby, let me begin with you. I don't know if you heard what Steve Forbes had to say but he basically said, Mark Zuckerberg dropped the ball on this and has to really be very careful this time on how he approaches it from now on. He has to instill confidence and he has to get it right. What we've seen up to now doesn't necessarily suggest he's able to do that.

SHELBY HOLLIDAY, SENIOR REPORTER, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": He's got to be honest because there are number of issues Facebook is dealing with right now, whether it's Russian meddling, Cambridge Analytica use of data, the cellphone and messages scraping if you will.

WEBSTER: Right.

HOLLIDAY: But the underlying theme for all of this is that users were not aware their data was being used against them. So now there's a lot of outrage. People are pledging to quit Facebook.

WEBSTER: Yes.

HOLLIDAY: They're calling for answers. You're hearing lawmakers really wanting the CEOs to get on the Hill and answer some of these questions. But Mark Zuckerberg is still continuing to sort of let this drip instead of just getting all the answers out there, confronting all of the problems they have and, quite frankly, being honest with all of the users, the two billion users Facebook has.

A lot of them when I talk to them, and I'm doing my reporting, still have no idea that they followed Russian accounts. So they're getting it from journalists, rather than the company itself.

WEBSTER: That's a good point. And Deirdre, you know, we hear today the FTC is getting involved. What could that mean?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: So that's like we're going to be -- one of the bigger questions is shall we -- you know, they had an agreement going back to 2011. So we should just say this is not the first time that the FTC and Facebook have sat down together. This is actually Facebook's second strike at that with the FTC.

So in 2011, they had an agreement about privacy, about use of data that Facebook agreed to. So I think one of the questions that Facebook is now going to have to answer is, did they follow the guidelines that they said they would in 2011?

WEBSTER: Right.

BOLTON: If it's found not, just start tacking on millions of dollars in fees, without even talking about potential regulation. But it's just actually literally going to cost them. So I think that's going to be one of the bigger questions.

I know with the android, so-called scraping. I actually spoke with somebody who said Facebook in legal thing, oh, but users did have the opt out. So once again, it's always the own us is on the user and we just keeping reminding ourselves, right, authors or media is you're not paying for the products, you are the product.

WEBSTER: Right.

BOLTON: So there is a bit of a buyer beware, which I think the Facebook legal side is going to try its best to argue. But I think long story short, honestly, this just opens the doors, as you said, invited to D.C. are now Mark Zuckerberg, Jack Dorsey, of course, for Twitter and Larry Page for Google. So I think, you know, what are these companies doing, how are they protecting our data? That's why the FTC is involved.

And you have spoken often with Scott Galloway, who's a professor at NYU --

WEBSTER: Yes, yes.

BOLTON: -- who actually believes there will be a call to break up big tech.

WEBSTER: Yes.

BOLTON: And he just wrote a book about this saying, it's going to come from Europe, because as he points out, Europe has all of the downside and none of the upside of big tech. Whereas, at least, we, in our country can brag like, oh, these are great businesses, we grow it here but Europe has none of that. They just have the downside.

WEBSTER: Yes, they just rely on finding the big American companies as part of their budget.

BOLTON: Right, yes.

WEBSTER: Shelby, let me ask you, should there be a presumption of privacy when you're posting on something that's so public as Facebook?

HOLLIDAY: That's a good question. You know, I think, throughout this debate what's getting lost is that users do have responsibility. We share TMI, to much information, all the time. So I definitely think if nothing else alerts people to the fact that their data is being used and they're sharing perhaps --

BORTON: Cambridge Analytica is saying, though, it was like quiz, though --

WEBSTER: It was.

BOLTON: -- and was like a personality profile.

HOLLIDAY: -- when you took this quiz years ago you had no idea it would come back to be served in your face in a political sense. And I think -- someone I spoke to last week made a really great point. Democracy is sort of built on this idea of open ideas, open debate.

WEBSTER: Right.

HOLLIDAY: And when you're sending targeted messages to people that no one knows what they say, no one knows how they might be manipulated there's no way for candidates or companies to refute these claims. They don't know what's being sent.

WEBSTER: I get the sense. We have to wrap this up. But I get the sense with Facebook is they really don't have any idea how much of your information is out there as we speak.

HOLLIDAY: No clue. And Zuckerberg is actually admitted that.

BOLTON: I think they built a machine that they can't manage. It's two billion users. It's too big even for them.

And you recall after our scandal, right, in the run-up to the U.S. Presidential election, 125 million U.S. voters saw that data. They hired 1000 editors, 1000 editors with two billion users? That proportion needs to be up. But then it cuts into profit margins if you're going to hire more humans.

WEBSTER: It's going to be very interesting. And we're going to be talking about it for a while. Great stuff. Shelby, Deirdre, thank you so much. Appreciate it.

HOLLIDAY: Thank you.

WEBSTER: President Trump, well, he's getting tough on Russia. The President ordering 60 Russian diplomats to pack their bags and get out of the U.S. It's in retaliation for the toxic nerve agent attack on a former Russian spy and his daughter on British soil. So what does this mean for U.S.-Russia relations from here? We'll talk about it next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: President Trump is expelling 60 Russian diplomats from the U.S. and is closing a Russian consulate in Seattle. This is in response to the nerve agent attack on an ex-Russian spy in the U.K. earlier this month. Now, the U.S. is joining at least 17 other countries in kicking out Russian diplomats making it the biggest western expulsion of Russian representatives since the height of the Cold War. Interesting stuff.

Here now with more, Philip Wegmann. He's a Commentary Writer for the "Washington Examiner."

Philip, do you think, do you get the sense that Vladmir Putin underestimated the response to this nerve agent attack in Britain? What is going through in his mind right now?

PHILIP WEGMANN, COMMENTARY WRITER, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": Well if Putin underestimated the response to that attack, he certainly understands the message that the Trump administration is sending right now. Remember, Putin is an old KGB hand and he is not going to miss the significance of the Trump administration kicking out 60 Russian diplomats and also closing that consulate in Seattle.

The message here is clear. It's that Russian cannot expect to manhandle our allies and get away with it. You can't perform these extra judicial executions on our allies' foreign soil. And, I think, we're just going to turn a blind eye.

WEBSTER: But is it symbolic? I mean, what impact does it really have? Sixty Russian diplomats and representatives go back to Moscow. Does it put a serious dent in the intelligence-gathering network?

WEGMANN: Absolutely. If you look at those diplomats, there were 60 of them and they were in Seattle, Washington, close to not only some of our sub-bases but also close to Boeing Manufacturing. So for us to push them out, that is significant blow to their intelligence gathering network.

And I think that what the Trump administration needs to do right now is they need to follow-up this strong action with strong words from the President. He needs to show that he's serious about this threat, because, frankly, a lot of people still don't know that this President now, by expelling those 60 Russian agents, has sent more Russians out of the country than President Obama did after the election with regard to the election meddling.

WEBSTER: Right. So we're fully expecting a tit-for-tat. We've seen the Russians do that with the U.K. when the U.K. kicked out 23 diplomats, same thing happened in Moscow. Probably the same thing is going to happen in the U.S. Does that not hurt our intelligence-gathering abilities in Russia?

WEGMANN: Well, you're absolutely right. Already the Russian embassy is tweeting this morning somewhat tongue-in-cheek, where and which consulates should be kicked out of Russia. You know, which of our agents should get the boot. And I think that because this is so pointed and this definitely is a blow at Russian intelligence, that Putin and company, they are going to strike back hard but the Trump administration has shown resolve, steel in this area. And now that John Bolton is joining the administration, someone who is a Russia hawk, I think we're going to see a much stronger response from the White House.

WEBSTER: How could have -- assuming this went all the way to Mr. Putin and he gave the OK for this, and we don't know that for sure, but it certainly appears that way, what was he trying to achieve? He had to know that something like this so brazen would have consequences.

WEGMANN: Well, the Russians are always trying to push the envelope and they're also very symbolic in the way that they carryout these executions. If you look at the type of nerve agent that was used, that was a clear calling card because that is an agent that was manufactured specifically in Russia. So he had to know there were these insidious bread crumbs that were going to lead back to the Kremlin.

I think what we're seeing here is that after the 2016 election, Putin is trying to feel out what he can do, how hard he can go after the United States. What we're seeing here is that Trump at least, with this reaction is showing that we are not going to back down from the world stage. That we are going to stand strong in our relations with some of our longest standing allies.

WEBSTER: I have to leave it right there. It'd be fascinating to follow what happens next. Philip, thank you so much for joining us. Appreciate it and thanks for your comments.

We are, of course, keeping a close eye on the markets for years. Stocks rally over trade talks, not a trade war. The market up 556 points now on the Dow, up at 24,083.

Also ahead, the court battle is underway to decide the fate of the AT&T merger with Time Warner. Right now, top broadcasting executives are testifying on what this merger would mean for them. We'll have the intel next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Witnesses are taken the stand today as the Department of Justice tries to block a potential multibillion dollar deal between AT&T and Time Warner. Joining me from the U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C., is our very own Connell McShane with the latest.

Hey, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Hey there, Ashley. Well, the court is just about to resume, to be back in session, coming back from one of your favorite activities, an extended lunch break which the judge took and for him the judge in this case, Richard Leon, this is a working lunch. It's kind of a strange morning.

We're waiting to hear from these two key executives in the cable industry. One of these guys named Warren Schlichting, a head of a Sling T.V., a DISH Network and the other is John Martin, the Chairman of CEO at Turner.

As the government tries to build this antitrust case and tries to block this merger of AT&T and Time Warner, I say it's a strange morning because what happened to us, just before the Department of Justice was to call its first witness of the day, the government lawyer asked the judge to approach the bench. And then for two hours, all the lawyers and the judge were talking.

Now, we're in the courtroom, we couldn't hear what they were saying so we don't know exactly what the issues were but we were told by judge, Leon, that some issues did come up and he had a number of e-mails to review. So he said let's take a longer break than usual. I'll review those e-mails and I'll come back and have some rulings and maybe we can proceed in the afternoon. So we'll see if we get that testimony. It could be important.

Just to get you up to speed, Ashley, in where we are. In this last week, the Justice Department started to make its case. Its basic case is that if these companies are allowed to combine, AT&T and Time Warner, it would be unfair and consumers would pay the price. They'd paid higher prices that AT&T would be able to kind of weaponize Time Warner to use the Justice Department's terms there and takes its networks HBO, and CNN, TNT, TBS to be able to leverage those with DirecTV service and increase prices.

The companies are comeback and argued that the Justice Department's case is fundamentally stuck in the past. They say the game is completely changed what to do competition from the tech companies whether the, Hulu, Netflix and the likes. So we're just getting started here, what could be a six to eight week trial. We'll see what this afternoon brings.

Back to you.

WEBSTER: So a lot of talking so far today, Connell, and you couldn't hear one word of it?

MCSHANE: Yes.

WEBSTER: Great stuff. All right. It's going to be a long six weeks, my friend. Enjoy those working lunches.

MCSHANE: I know.

WEBSTER: All right, Connell McShane down in D.C. on the latest development in AT&T-Time Warner merger case.

Stops our rallying as investors cheer on reports of trade negotiations, nice press negotiations between the U.S. and China. Let's go to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, where our very own Nicole Petallides has the latest.

Big sell-off last week? We're up 545 points. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: That's right. So cooler heads prevailed for today but big picture, people think of the hard time committing to that is going to be a great 2018 because there are so many factors up in the air, they're looking at technicals.

Right now, the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 545 points, the S&P 500 is up, 2.1 percent. Third day in a row of two percent move. Thursday, Friday down two percent each of those days and today up two percent. So the volatility is here.

Tech, we have this interesting dichotomy, fang, right? Facebook being the F. There's seems to be a separation on this one. In fact, some people are even wondering is fang over because Facebook under pressure again, down 1.5 percent for the month, down 12.2 percent as it remain under fire.

Zuckerberg actually has been invited to testify in the U.S. Senate. You could see that it's down 1.6 percent. But Apple, Alphabet, Google, Microsoft, IBM all gaining today.

Financials, this could actually did slightly worse than even the techs on Friday. Without financials and technology these markets have a very hard time trying to get off the ground. But here's on what's J.P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley, Goldman, all up more than three percent. And Katie W. (ph) put out a note today saying that they say mergers and acquisitions ahead, and particularly for J.P. Morgan and Goldman Sachs being the acquirers.

Last but not least, a quick look at defense stocks as we know that the President and assigning in new obviously military spending a massive a boost to this group on Friday. You can see here, Lockheed, Northrop, Bowman, General Dynamics all up more than two percent each. So that trend continues.

Back to you.

WEBSTER: Lots of green arrows. Nicole, thank you very much.

Meanwhile, one of the oldest gunmakers in the U.S. is filing for bankruptcy. Remington Arms is restructuring its massive debt after a 30 percent drop in gun sales this year. The filing will allow the 200-year- old company to stay in business while reducing its debt by $700 million. It will, by the way, continue to make guns during the bankruptcy proceedings.

And Elon Musk's boring company, and I don't mean boring as dull, I mean the one that makes tunnels in the ground is going to sell Lego-like bricks made from tunneling rock. The life-sized interlocking blocks will be used to build low-cost homes and other structures. Those bricks will be lightweight and durable, making them easy to assemble, Lego bricks.

Obamacare premiums are set to go up right before the midterm elections in November. We'll have the intel on what this could mean for both parties in the midterms next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Health care premiums are expected to go up yet again right before the midterm elections in November. Now this after a battle in Congress failed to include in last week's massive spending bill a plan to shore up the health insurance exchanges. No subsidies. And without the government money, insurance companies, well you know what they're going to do? They're going to raise rates, right?

Gerri Willis joins us live from the newsroom with the latest on this. Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Well, Ash, you've got that story right. Estimates of just how much premiums could rise, according to the Congressional Budget Office, some 10 percent for a popular middle priced option on the insurance exchanges and, you know, that doesn't even include the hike to premiums that will likely occur as the mandate fades away.

Now, lawmakers on both sides are pointing fingers, Democrats blame the GOP for failure in negotiations saying they demanded abortion restrictions being included something they knew would be unacceptable to Democrats. And Republicans say this that they negotiated in good faith and Democrats rejected reasonable rules on abortion. Either way, the impasse means money to shore up the Obamacare insurance exchanges was omitted from the $1.3 trillion spending plan that the President signed last week.

Failing to shore up, the exchanges could have big repercussions at the ballot box. A recent poll in Pennsylvania showed health care was a top issue for 52 percent of voters according to Public Policy Polling.

Payments to insurers were stopped last year after President Trump said they were illegal because the money had not been appropriated by Congress. Meanwhile, insiders say that passage of legislation to stabilize the exchanges, highly unlikely.

Ash, back to you.

WEBSTER: Interesting stuff. The bottom line is those rates go up. Gerri, thank you very much.

Health care is expected to be one of the top issues for this year's midterm elections. Topping the latest "Q-poll" as the number one issue and poll show that most voters feel Democrats would handle health care better, but a new Fox poll shows the Democrats lead in the midterms is actually slipping to just five points. Interesting.

Joining me now, Former Bush Administration Aide, Matt Mackowiak, and Democratic Strategist, Antjuan Seawright. Thank you both for being here.

Matt, let me begin with you. You could argue that health care continues to be a problem and it was failure of the Republicans who have the House in Senate and Oval Office to get this thing sorted out. How would you respond?

MATT MACKOWIAK, FORMER BUSH ADMINISTRATION AIDE: Yes, there's no question that Republicans promised to repeal and replace Obamacare. The House took two attempts and got it done. The Senate took two attempts and failed by one vote and so Republican voters have some frustration about that, there's no question. But that's going to be one be one issue the midterms are going to be about. They're going to be about economy, they're going to be about direction of the country and they're ultimately going to be about the candidates that running on both sides, you know, in each district.

The generic ballot is helpful directionally. But ultimately every individual race comes down to that district, comes down to the candidates that are running, the campaigns they're running. We saw that in Pennsylvania 18 where the Democratic candidate ran as pro-gun, personally anti-abortion, Democratic candidate.

WEBSTER: Right.

MACKOWIAK: And that's not what you're going to see in a lot of other races around the country.

WEBSTER: Antjuan, let me ask you. Why do you think the gap is closing in the polls? What do you put that down to?

ANTJUAN SEAWRIGHT, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, a couple of things here, one, you should know that between now and November this will be a marathon, not a sprint on both sides.

WEBSTER: True.

SEAWRIGHT: So you're going to see the polls change, go up and down from here until November. The second thing to remember is that the enthusiasm gap favors the Democrats as well as history. It is very uncommon for the party in charge to keep their charge in the midterm elections.

And the third thing that I will tell you, if you look what is happening all across the country, in special elections whether State House seats, Alabama, New Jersey, Virginia, even in Pennsylvania, the voters are speaking out very loudly. They are rejecting the policies of Donald Trump and the Republican Party. I think the Republicans have a big issue in November and what no poll will be able to tell you this point is the massive enthusiasm we've seen from the Women's March movement just a few months ago in Washington as well as these young people all across the country who are organizing.

WEBSTER: Antjuan, let me just follow up very quickly. Matt mentioned the economy. The tax reform has put up more money in a lot of people's pockets and the economy for all intents and purposes is doing very well. If you hang your hat on the economy, how are you going to make that argument?

SEAWRIGHT: Well, I think the economy will be just one issue that voters will decide on. But here's the thing to remember about the economy, there is a reason why the Republican Party did not run one single ad in Pennsylvania about their tax scam that they passed a few months ago because the voters do not agree what happened.

Look, that bonus they received in their check, I'm not saying it's not a good thing but it was a shot in the arm. What want people are raise in wages that will sustain them long term and improve their quality of life, and middle class families over the long term will not see that from the tax bill that passed a few months ago by the Republicans.

WEBSTER: Matt, let me have you respond to Antjuan. I mean, you know, yes, the bonuses were nice. They weren't crumbs but they're also seeing benefits from the tax reform paying lower taxes.

MACKOWIAK: No question. You have about 5 million people who received their bonus or received their wage increase because of the tax law, that's significant. You have the highest consumer confidence we've had in decades. And I can put Antjuan's mind at ease, wages are going up for first time in a decade and that's very good news.

SEAWRIGHT: Well they're not, Matt, according to statistics. According to statistics wages are flat.

MACKOWIAK: Antjuan, I'd be happy to send you the statistics that have come out on the last couple months that shown wages have begun rising. So the economy is improving. It's strengthening. We have 4.1 percent unemployment and historically very, very low.

And I think Republicans everyday they aren't talking about the economy as a waste. They need to talk about the economy. They need to sell the tax law. A majority of the public is now viewing it very favorably. This has a chance to save their majority even though it is very much up for grabs.

WEBSTER: Antjuan, do you think that --

SEAWRIGHT: Matt, keep in mind --

WEBSTER: -- all right, go ahead.

SEAWRIGHT: -- Matt, keep in mind, the one thing that you all have around your neck is President Donald Trump, the most toxic President probably in modern-day history at the top of the ticket. Look, that is not a good thing going into someone --

WEBSTER: But why is his approval rating Antjuan? Why is the President's approval rating going up?

SEAWRIGHT: -- it may be rising from the graveyard but it has not hit aboveground just yet. And keep in mind, Virginia rejected, Alabama rejected Trump, so did Pennsylvania and in districts where he carried about 20, 30 points in the last election cycle. Democrats have been winning at various levels of our government. And so, you can decide however you want to break that down, but I am telling you that something is brewing here in this country and I don't think the way will be in favor of Republicans.

WEBSTER: Very quickly, Matt. You know, if you're a candidate, do you want Donald Trump to come to your town and stamp for you and, you know, get the crowd fired up? Would you distance yourself?

MACKOWIAK: It totally depends on district and on the dynamics of the race that you're in.

WEBSTER: Right.

MACKOWIAK: In some districts, particularly in places like California you probably don't want the President to come in. If you're in the middle of country, in states that Trump won, if you're running for U.S. Senate in North Dakota or West Virginia or Montana, the President can be very helpful. So, they're going to have to be strategic on how they deploy him next fall.

There's no question, his improvement has been narrowly increasing. He's in the middle of 30s last year. It's in the low 40s now. They needed to get in the mid-40s by the midterms. They'll have a chance to hold the House and that's very important.

WEBSTER: Guys, we have to leave it right there. You know, bottom line is a day is a long time in politics. So, there is a long time between now and November.

MACKOWIAK: A marathon, not a sprint.

WEBSTER: All right. Matt and Antjuan, great stuff as always. Thank you both for joining us today.

SEAWRIGHT: Thank you.

MACKOWIAK: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Coming up next, we got preview of tonight's new episodes of the "Strange Inheritance," including a son of a NASA chaplain who inherits more than a 100 Bibles that went to the moon. I kid you not. Stay with us. We're back in two.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Monday night on Fox Business are getting a just little bit stranger. Strange Inheritance is back tonight with two new episodes, one, involving some Bibles that went all the way to the moon. I kid you not. Take a look.

(BEGINNING VIDEO CLIP)

JAMIE COLBY, HOST, "STRANGE INHERITANCE": It's a small postage stamp. What's on there?

JONATHAN STOUT: That's the entire Bible.

COLBY: On one little tiny microfiche?

STOUT: On each sheet.

COLBY: When it's magnified under a microscope, sure enough there is the Holy Scripture.

STOUT: That was my dad's dream, to get the Bible to the moon.

COLBY: Wait, your inheritance is this little teeny-tiny Bibles went to the moon?

COLBY: Yes, it did.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

Jamie, thank you so much for being here.

COLBY: Absolutely, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Define Bible.

COLBY: Did you know I did not know Bibles went to the moon.

WEBSTER: No.

COLBY: But Reverend Stout was.

WEBSTER: And they came back. They weren't left there for someone to read.

COLBY: Well, it took several attempts to get them there successfully to be on the lunar surface. He was really determined. He was NASA engineer who happened to be at Reverend and he decided this is something he wanted to do.

So, Edgar Mitchell was the astronaut that actually took it as part of his personal items, hundreds of them, because they were that small. I don't even know how many people remember microfiche but I read and the entire Bible was there.

WEBSTER: I'm old enough to remember microfiche at the library, you know, you go through.

COLBY: But here's the problem. You want to know what their worst because this is a business channel.

WEBSTER: Always.

COLBY: They are so valuable. The individual ones have sold anywhere from 10,000 to 70,000.

WEBSTER: You are kidding.

COLBY: He has several hundred of them but there wasn't a will and even though when there's a will there's a way. When there's no will it's get very complicated on Strange Inheritance.

So, tonight, you'll meet the family. You'll also meet an author, Carol Mersch, who did some investigation and story on the Bibles with Reverend and she says, the Bibles belonged to her.

WEBSTER: Interesting.

COLBY: It's a little messy.

WEBSTER: Yes. That's the best you say.

COLBY: The good book on demand.

WEBSTER: When it comes with the territory, when you're talking about things that are, you know, left behind, if the ownership part is not clear it can get, well, down right ugly at times. Anyway, --

COLBY: In Texas, they're good people. They're going to work it out.

WEBSTER: -- of course they will. Now, also, there's another topic you're getting into involving race cars.

COLBY: Rave up you engine because --

WEBSTER: Best car?

COLBY: -- this family, actually the father, Mickey Thompson, broke the land speed records at the Bonneville Salt Flats on what he called the Challenger. It's a piston-driven engine that goes 400 plus miles.

WEBSTER: Look at that. Oh my God!

COLBY: Wait till you see me in it. But anyway I degrease that so much fun. I could almost knock it out. It's so high speed.

WEBSTER: You still be in and out.

COLBY: It was amazing. So, Danny is his son and he was determined to break his dad's land speed record because for all the years his father told him, no racing, it's dangerous.

WEBSTER: Oh, my God. Yes.

COLBY: The last thing his father said to him is I'm giving you the Challenger. I want you to race it and now, he's determined to make sure that the Thompson family keeps that record.

WEBSTER: Fascinating. The air tonight beginning at?

COLBY: 9:00 to 9:30.

WEBSTER: 9:00 to 9:30.

COLBY: Come on over.

WEBSTER: I'd love it. I want to try that car, break the land speed record or may be not. At least you got of it, that's the main thing.

COLBY: Wear your seatbelt, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Yes, always. Jamie, thank you very much.

Let's take a look at the market for you. What a day. We said it's a Jamie Colby effect. It was going to hit 600 points, nearly Jamie. Good. We're up 564 points.

Liz Claman, by the way, is back from, I think, she went skiing. I think she went old fancy and went out west to go skiing.

We saw some picture, Liz. You looked terrific out there. And you're into friend. I think you ride into Peter Toughman (ph)

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Can you believe that.

WEBSTER: Of all of people, I mean, it's a small world because Peter Toughman works down at the New York Exchange. He's the guy with that crazy hair and the glasses. And he's taking picture when the markets doing crazy thing.

CLAMAN: He is the most photographed trader on the floor of the New York Stock. We're going to find that picture up the Twitter feed.

LIZ: But I can tell you, he wasn't wearing a helmet.

WEBSTER: What?

CLAMAN: Bad, Peter, bad. That's how I recognize him because out there with his hair.

WEBSTER: Funny. He looks funny in a helmet. Yes.

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I think he has a no choice there.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I think so, too. Yes, they'll send a car right over to take him down there, I think. Neil Cavuto. Thanks, Neil. Appreciate it.

CAVUTO: All right, bud.

WEBSTER: Breaking right now, stocks are soaring after new reports suggest that the White House is quietly negotiating with China as both sides tried to avoid an all-out trade war.

Hello, everybody. I'm Ashley Webster, in today for Trish Regan. And welcome, everyone, to "The Intelligence Report."

Well, investors are encourage by the prospect of the world's two largest economies reaching the deal on trade as stocks bounce back from their worst week in more than two years and optimism apparently spreading beyond Wall Street. Here is Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin speaking to Fox News just yesterday.

Ash, back to you.

WEBSTER: Interesting stuff. The bottom line is those rates go up. Gerri, thank you very much.

Health care is expected to be one of the top issues for this year's midterm elections. Topping the latest "Q-poll" as the number one issue and poll show that most voters feel Democrats would handle health care better, but a new Fox poll shows the Democrats lead in the midterms is actually slipping to just five points. Interesting.

Joining me now, Former Bush Administration Aide, Matt Mackowiak, and Democratic Strategist, Antjuan Seawright. Thank you both for being here.

Matt, let me begin with you. You could argue that health care continues to be a problem and it was failure of the Republicans who have the House in Senate and Oval Office to get this thing sorted out. How would you respond?

MATT MACKOWIAK, FORMER BUSH ADMINISTRATION AIDE: Yes, there's no question that Republicans promised to repeal and replace Obamacare. The House took two attempts and got it done. The Senate took two attempts and failed by one vote and so Republican voters have some frustration about that, there's no question. But that's going to be one be one issue the midterms are going to be about. They're going to be about economy, they're going to be about direction of the country and they're ultimately going to be about the candidates that running on both sides, you know, in each district.

The generic ballot is helpful directionally. But ultimately every individual race comes down to that district, comes down to the candidates that are running, the campaigns they're running. We saw that in Pennsylvania 18 where the Democratic candidate ran as pro-gun, personally anti-abortion, Democratic candidate.

WEBSTER: Right.

MACKOWIAK: And that's not what you're going to see in a lot of other races around the country.

WEBSTER: Antjuan, let me ask you. Why do you think the gap is closing in the polls? What do you put that down to?

ANTJUAN SEAWRIGHT, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, a couple of things here, one, you should know that between now and November this will be a marathon, not a sprint on both sides.

WEBSTER: True.

SEAWRIGHT: So you're going to see the polls change, go up and down from here until November. The second thing to remember is that the enthusiasm gap favors the Democrats as well as history. It is very uncommon for the party in charge to keep their charge in the midterm elections.

And the third thing that I will tell you, if you look what is happening all across the country, in special elections whether State House seats, Alabama, New Jersey, Virginia, even in Pennsylvania, the voters are speaking out very loudly. They are rejecting the policies of Donald Trump and the Republican Party. I think the Republicans have a big issue in November and what no poll will be able to tell you this point is the massive enthusiasm we've seen from the Women's March movement just a few months ago in Washington as well as these young people all across the country who are organizing.

WEBSTER: Antjuan, let me just follow up very quickly. Matt mentioned the economy. The tax reform has put up more money in a lot of people's pockets and the economy for all intents and purposes is doing very well. If you hang your hat on the economy, how are you going to make that argument?

SEAWRIGHT: Well, I think the economy will be just one issue that voters will decide on. But here's the thing to remember about the economy, there is a reason why the Republican Party did not run one single ad in Pennsylvania about their tax scam that they passed a few months ago because the voters do not agree what happened.

Look, that bonus they received in their check, I'm not saying it's not a good thing but it was a shot in the arm. What want people are raise in wages that will sustain them long term and improve their quality of life, and middle class families over the long term will not see that from the tax bill that passed a few months ago by the Republicans.

WEBSTER: Matt, let me have you respond to Antjuan. I mean, you know, yes, the bonuses were nice. They weren't crumbs but they're also seeing benefits from the tax reform paying lower taxes.

MACKOWIAK: No question. You have about 5 million people who received their bonus or received their wage increase because of the tax law, that's significant. You have the highest consumer confidence we've had in decades. And I can put Antjuan's mind at ease, wages are going up for first time in a decade and that's very good news.

SEAWRIGHT: Well they're not, Matt, according to statistics. According to statistics wages are flat.

MACKOWIAK: Antjuan, I'd be happy to send you the statistics that have come out on the last couple months that shown wages have begun rising. So the economy is improving. It's strengthening. We have 4.1 percent unemployment and historically very, very low.

And I think Republicans everyday they aren't talking about the economy as a waste. They need to talk about the economy. They need to sell the tax law. A majority of the public is now viewing it very favorably. This has a chance to save their majority even though it is very much up for grabs.

WEBSTER: Antjuan, do you think that --

SEAWRIGHT: Matt, keep in mind --

WEBSTER: -- all right, go ahead.

SEAWRIGHT: -- Matt, keep in mind, the one thing that you all have around your neck is President Donald Trump, the most toxic President probably in modern-day history at the top of the ticket. Look, that is not a good thing going into someone --

WEBSTER: But why is his approval rating Antjuan? Why is the President's approval rating going up?

SEAWRIGHT: -- it may be rising from the graveyard but it has not hit aboveground just yet. And keep in mind, Virginia rejected, Alabama rejected Trump, so did Pennsylvania and in districts where he carried about 20, 30 points in the last election cycle. Democrats have been winning at various levels of our government. And so, you can decide however you want to break that down, but I am telling you that something is brewing here in this country and I don't think the way will be in favor of Republicans.

WEBSTER: Very quickly, Matt. You know, if you're a candidate, do you want Donald Trump to come to your town and stamp for you and, you know, get the crowd fired up? Would you distance yourself?

MACKOWIAK: It totally depends on district and on the dynamics of the race that you're in.

WEBSTER: Right.

MACKOWIAK: In some districts, particularly in places like California you probably don't want the President to come in. If you're in the middle of country, in states that Trump won, if you're running for U.S. Senate in North Dakota or West Virginia or Montana, the President can be very helpful. So, they're going to have to be strategic on how they deploy him next fall.

There's no question, his improvement has been narrowly increasing. He's in the middle of 30s last year. It's in the low 40s now. They needed to get in the mid-40s by the midterms. They'll have a chance to hold the House and that's very important.

WEBSTER: Guys, we have to leave it right there. You know, bottom line is a day is a long time in politics. So, there is a long time between now and November.

MACKOWIAK: A marathon, not a sprint.

WEBSTER: All right. Matt and Antjuan, great stuff as always. Thank you both for joining us today.

SEAWRIGHT: Thank you.

MACKOWIAK: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Coming up next, we got preview of tonight's new episodes of the "Strange Inheritance," including a son of a NASA chaplain who inherits more than a 100 Bibles that went to the moon. I kid you not. Stay with us. We're back in two.

(BEGINNING VIDEO CLIP)

JAMIE COLBY, HOST, "STRANGE INHERITANCE": It's a small postage stamp. What's on there?

Jamie, thank you so much for being here.

COLBY: Absolutely, Ashley.

So, tonight, you'll meet the family. You'll also meet an author, Carol Mersch, who did some investigation and story on the Bibles with Reverend and she says, the Bibles belonged to her.

COLBY: It's a little messy.

WEBSTER: When it comes with the territory, when you're talking about things that are, you know, left behind, if the ownership part is not clear it can get, well, down right ugly at times. Anyway, --

COLBY: Rave up you engine because --

COLBY: -- this family, actually the father, Mickey Thompson, broke the land speed records at the Bonneville Salt Flats on what he called the Challenger. It's a piston-driven engine that goes 400 plus miles.

COLBY: Wait till you see me in it. But anyway I degrease that so much fun. I could almost knock it out. It's so high speed.

COLBY: It was amazing. So, Danny is his son and he was determined to break his dad's land speed record because for all the years his father told him, no racing, it's dangerous.

COLBY: The last thing his father said to him is I'm giving you the Challenger. I want you to race it and now, he's determined to make sure that the Thompson family keeps that record.

WEBSTER: Fascinating. The air tonight beginning at?

COLBY: 9:00 to 9:30.

WEBSTER: 9:00 to 9:30.

COLBY: Come on over.

WEBSTER: I'd love it. I want to try that car, break the land speed record or may be not. At least you got of it, that's the main thing.

COLBY: Wear your seatbelt, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Yes, always. Jamie, thank you very much.

Let's take a look at the market for you. What a day. We said it's a Jamie Colby effect. It was going to hit 600 points, nearly Jamie. Good. We're up 564 points.

Liz Claman, by the way, is back from, I think, she went skiing. I think she went old fancy and went out west to go skiing.

We saw some picture, Liz. You looked terrific out there. And you're into friend. I think you ride into Peter Toughman (ph)

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Can you believe that.

WEBSTER: Of all of people, I mean, it's a small world because Peter Toughman works down at the New York Exchange. He's the guy with that crazy hair and the glasses. And he's taking picture when the markets doing crazy thing.

CLAMAN: He is the most photographed trader on the floor of the New York Stock. We're going to find that picture up the Twitter feed.

LIZ: But I can tell you, he wasn't wearing a helmet.

CLAMAN: Bad, Peter, bad. That's how I recognize him because out there with his hair.

WEBSTER: Funny. He looks funny in a helmet. Yes.

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I think he has a no choice there.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I think so, too. Yes, they'll send a car right over to take him down there, I think. Neil Cavuto. Thanks, Neil. Appreciate it.

CAVUTO: All right, bud.

WEBSTER: Breaking right now, stocks are soaring after new reports suggest that the White House is quietly negotiating with China as both sides tried to avoid an all-out trade war.

Hello, everybody. I'm Ashley Webster, in today for Trish Regan. And welcome, everyone, to "The Intelligence Report."

Well, investors are encourage by the prospect of the world's two largest economies reaching the deal on trade as stocks bounce back from their worst week in more than two years and optimism apparently spreading beyond Wall Street. Here is Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin speaking to Fox News just yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: I think we're working on a pathway to see if we can reach an agreement as to what fair trade is for them to open up their markets, reduce their tariffs, stop force-technology transfer. These are all the things we want to do. But in a negotiation, you have to be prepared to take action and that's what President Trump is doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: He certainly is. The President displaying his confidence in our economy in a tweet this morning saying, "The economy is looking really good. It has been years that we have seen these kind of numbers. The underlying strength of companies has perhaps never been better." And we'll find out ow those companies are doing, of course, next month with the latest round of earnings.

Joining me now Forbes Media Chairman, the man himself, Steve Forbes. And, Steve, thank you very much for joining us today in the studio.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

WEBSTER: OK. Let's just pick up from what the President said, are you happy with the U.S. economy heading in the right direction. Is it healthy?

FORBES: I think it is healthy. And I think there were news coming out about negotiating with China and these trade disputes is a good thing because one of the things this imposition of tariffs would have done is create uncertainty. Is this thing going to spin out of control?

On the steel side for Japan and China is now been exempted to further negotiations. On the Chinese side, working behind the scenes see what can be done. So I think the markets and investors will be reassured, OK, we can invest. They're not going to let this thing spin out of control.

WEBSTER: Even though, let's be honest, the way its approach is a little chaotic. The Trump administration and it was on this campaign promise list, if you like, so it's not a big surprise but it really did shake the markets. But is this, in your opinion, a classic Donald Trump maneuver? Shoot very high, come out strong, and then bring someone to the table and negotiate perhaps something a little lower?

FORBES: Well, I think, that it would have been better for him and for the economy and investing confidence if they had first, especially with China, negotiated with our European allies, saying we know there are abusers. Our allies know there are abusers. We're going to present the United Front.

Here's what we're going to put on the table. So, you've done that kind of preparation, one, the market wouldn't have freaked out and, two, everyone would have acknowledged, yes, this thing has to be addressed.

WEBSTER: These market actions are remarkable. I was on the 3:00 show last week when we had a 400 point drop and a 700 point drop. Here we go again, the volatility is back. Everything seems now is headline driven. Is that going to be the way for awhile now, do you believe?

FORBES: Well, this is going to depend on what you've referred to early. These earnings are starting to come out next month. But it looks like Corporate America is starting to still turning in good profits.

People say, OK, things are still being done, things are moving ahead. Heck, there was even a story this weekend about "Brexit" in Britain.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FORBES: But for all the hoopla in parliament and the disarray and the ineffective prime minister, things are happening in the economy. It's amazing. Government leaves it alone.

WEBSTER: Despite everything.

FORBES: People do things.

WEBSTER: Well, it's interesting. How much attention does the market or investors pay to what's going on in Washington, because every day there's some headline coming out, whether it's the President's personal lawyer quits or whatever it'd be the story de jure. Does that have an impact on the markets? Are people able to put the noise aside?

FORBES: Most of the noise they put aside, as we've seen with the markets reaction to recently, when concerns about what's going to happen on the trade front came to the forefront. That's when markets thought, my golly, are they going to let this thing spin out of control? Are they going to control it? And so, they respond to that kind of news, not to the latest thing on "60 Minutes" or anything else.

WEBSTER: I know. That's not even news as far I can see it. But anyway, we'll move on.

I have to ask you about Facebook, because in light of the 444 point gain today on Wall Street, it's been striking what we've seen with the selling on Facebook and the hits it continues to take today. We found out the Federal Trade Commission has begun the investigation. Do you have a Facebook page?

FORBES: I do and even own a few shares of Facebook.

WEBSTER: Right. What's your take on all of this?

FORBES: But I think it's a case where management has flubbed the ball. This thing could have been contained from the beginning, be upfront about it. Outline what you're going to do to prevent abuses by users.

Yes, the users violated the contract. But what follow-up did you have? What kind of auditing did you have?

Reassure that you're on top of the things, instead of look like you're floundering, you don't know what to do. You want to go on apology tour. That freaks people out that you're not in charge.

WEBSTER: Is this redeemable at this stage because it's a very good chance to, as Neil Cavuto said, look, he's going to be down in Washington testifying?

FORBES: Yes, and that's like I have an offer you can't refuse kind of invitation.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FORBES: That's going to be critical because that will determine the fate of the stocks in the months ahead, if he goes before the committee and says, here's what happened, here's what we're outlining doing. We think we're on top of this thing, present a role that he is in charge and reassuring and confident, instead of floundering.

WEBSTER: We haven't seen it so far.

FORBES: We haven't seen it, but this is his chance to do it. I hope he is prepping for this thing in a way people say, OK, the government is not going to really move in a big way because if the government moves in, that stock is going to be killed.

WEBSTER: It is. And we're talking about new regulations which could further crimp the business model of Facebook and other social media companies.

FORBES: Yes, and not only Facebook but it means they're going to end up gumming up a lot of other high-tech companies and high-tech start-ups. We don't have the resources to fight this kind thing. So a lot is on his shoulder. I hope the shoulders are broad --

WEBSTER: But don't blow it as they say, Steve.

FORBES: -- well, he brought it on.

WEBSTER: He did, that's very true. Steve, thank you very much. Great stuff as always.

FORBES: Thank you.

WEBSTER: For more on these markets, let's bring in the Stock Swoosh Founder, Melissa Armo, along with Surevest Wealth Management CEO, Rob Luna.

Melissa, let me get to you. What's your take on the markets right now? You need some Pepto-Bismol, don't you? We had a big selloff last week and now here were are up 443 points. Is pretty much this volatility here to stay?

MELISSA ARMO, THE STOCK SWOOSH: Volatility is here to stay. Came in in 2018. I don't think it's going anywhere.

I really didn't look today as a strong day. I know we gapped up a lot this morning. But overall, this is just kind of like a dead-cat bounce, it's something that traders use the terminology.

I really think we might still be lower, because the fact is that overall the market is strong but everything that happens, every headline that comes out, every news thing, the market is reacting very volatile to it, selling off quickly and then bouncing again and selling off quickly.

WEBSTER: Yes.

ARMO: And the range is broadening. We're still strong but the range from the high to where we're at in this base is like wide, it's getting wider and wider and wider.

WEBSTER: Well, it's interesting because, Rob, you say, look, we are trading in a range but to Melissa's point, that range is like the size of the Grand Canyon right now.

ROB LUNA, CEO, SUREVEST WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Well, it's like the size of the Grand Canyon. If you look at the minuscule ranges that we're trading in over the prior 18 to 24 months but I think, you know, in general, there's 11 to 12 percentage point range that we're trading in, you know, quiet honestly, Ashley, is normal. WEBSTER: You know, it's fascinating. Joining me now in the studio to chat about all of the Strange Inheritance stamp, and it is fascinating, is the host, Jamie Colby.

Jamie, thank you so much for being here.

COLBY: Absolutely, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Define Bible.

COLBY: Did you know I did not know Bibles went to the moon.

WEBSTER: No.

COLBY: But Reverend Stout was.

WEBSTER: And they came back. They weren't left there for someone to read.

COLBY: Well, it took several attempts to get them there successfully to be on the lunar surface. He was really determined. He was NASA engineer who happened to be at Reverend and he decided this is something he wanted to do.

So, Edgar Mitchell was the astronaut that actually took it as part of his personal items, hundreds of them, because they were that small. I don't even know how many people remember microfiche but I read and the entire Bible was there.

WEBSTER: I'm old enough to remember microfiche at the library, you know, you go through.

COLBY: But here's the problem. You want to know what their worst because this is a business channel.

WEBSTER: Always.

COLBY: They are so valuable. The individual ones have sold anywhere from 10,000 to 70,000.

WEBSTER: You are kidding.

COLBY: He has several hundred of them but there wasn't a will and even though when there's a will there's a way. When there's no will it's get very complicated on Strange Inheritance.

So, tonight, you'll meet the family. You'll also meet an author, Carol Mersch, who did some investigation and story on the Bibles with Reverend and she says, the Bibles belonged to her.

WEBSTER: Interesting.

COLBY: It's a little messy.

WEBSTER: Yes. That's the best you say.

COLBY: The good book on demand.

WEBSTER: When it comes with the territory, when you're talking about things that are, you know, left behind, if the ownership part is not clear it can get, well, down right ugly at times. Anyway, --

COLBY: In Texas, they're good people. They're going to work it out.

WEBSTER: -- of course they will. Now, also, there's another topic you're getting into involving race cars.

COLBY: Rave up you engine because --

WEBSTER: Best car?

COLBY: -- this family, actually the father, Mickey Thompson, broke the land speed records at the Bonneville Salt Flats on what he called the Challenger. It's a piston-driven engine that goes 400 plus miles.

WEBSTER: Look at that. Oh my God!

COLBY: Wait till you see me in it. But anyway I degrease that so much fun. I could almost knock it out. It's so high speed.

WEBSTER: You still be in and out.

COLBY: It was amazing. So, Danny is his son and he was determined to break his dad's land speed record because for all the years his father told him, no racing, it's dangerous.

WEBSTER: Oh, my God. Yes.

COLBY: The last thing his father said to him is I'm giving you the Challenger. I want you to race it and now, he's determined to make sure that the Thompson family keeps that record.

WEBSTER: Fascinating. The air tonight beginning at?

COLBY: 9:00 to 9:30.

WEBSTER: 9:00 to 9:30.

COLBY: Come on over.

WEBSTER: I'd love it. I want to try that car, break the land speed record or may be not. At least you got of it, that's the main thing.

COLBY: Wear your seatbelt, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Yes, always. Jamie, thank you very much.

Let's take a look at the market for you. What a day. We said it's a Jamie Colby effect. It was going to hit 600 points, nearly Jamie. Good. We're up 564 points.

Liz Claman, by the way, is back from, I think, she went skiing. I think she went old fancy and went out west to go skiing.

We saw some picture, Liz. You looked terrific out there. And you're into friend. I think you ride into Peter Toughman (ph)

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Can you believe that.

WEBSTER: Of all of people, I mean, it's a small world because Peter Toughman works down at the New York Exchange. He's the guy with that crazy hair and the glasses. And he's taking picture when the markets doing crazy thing.

CLAMAN: He is the most photographed trader on the floor of the New York Stock. We're going to find that picture up the Twitter feed.

WEBSTER: We do. It's great to have you back.

LIZ: But I can tell you, he wasn't wearing a helmet.

WEBSTER: What?

CLAMAN: Bad, Peter, bad. That's how I recognize him because out there with his hair.

WEBSTER: Funny. He looks funny in a helmet. Yes.

END
